monogr.title: The Psalter of Dauid : newely translated into Englysh metre in such sort that it maye the more decently, and wyth more delyte of the mynde, be reade and songe of al men. Wherunto is added a note of four partes, wyth other thynges, as shall appeare in the epistle to the readar

div.head: ¶ To the Christian Readar.
div.p: LEste thou shouldest be ignorant in anye thynge that is conteyned in thys boke (gentle readar) haue here the vnderstandynge of the table yt I haue sette before the kalender. First thou muste seke the Golden number, which thys yere of our Lorde. M.D.xlix.is.xj. and standeth in the fyrst ende of the rowe of numbers folowynge .xi.xij.xiij.xiiij.xv.xvi.xvij.xviij.xix.i.ij.iij.iiij.v.vi.vij.viij.ix.x. The next yere it shalbe .xii. and so forth, so that thys tyme .xix. yeres it shalbe xi. agayne.
Then must ye knowe the sundayes letter whych is founde after this sorte.

In the firste ende of thys rowe of letters standeth .f. whyche is sundayes letter thys yere of our Lorde. M.D.xlix. the next yere shalbe .e. and so forth as they stande in order, and where .ij. letters be, ther is leape yere.
So that thys tyme .xxviij. Yeres: f. in the firste ende of the rowe, shalbe sunnedayes letter agayne.

This done, loke the golden numbre at the leafte side of your table, & then the sundayes letter next folowynge, agaynste which you shall fynde all the moueable feastes noted, what moneth and daye of the moneth they fall.

And here note, that if the golden number stande agaynste the sundayes letter thou shalt not take that sundayes letter, but the next sundayes letter folowynge. And when thou comest to the ende of the table, begyne it agayne, as though it were rownde and had none ende.

Thou hast also in this boke, a note or song of .iiij. partes, which agreth wyth the metre of this Psalter in suche sorte, that it serueth for all the Psalmes therof, conteynynge so many notes in one parte, as be syllables in one meter, as appeareth by the dyttie that is printed wyth the same.
More ouer, I haue added to the ende of this boke, all the canticles that are vsually songe in the church, translated into the same meter, and agreynge wyth the same note.

This haue I done, to moue the to delyte in the readynge and hearynge of these Psalmes, wherin lyeth hyd the most preciouse
treasure of the christian religion. And so far as my knowledge woulde serue me: I haue made open and playne, that whiche in other translations, is obscure & harde. Trustynge that some better learned, wyll hereat take occasion to adde more lyght. In the meane tyme geue God the glorie for that he hath done in me, and praye that thou mayest alwayes credite the infallible trueth of goddes worde. And if thou chaunce to confer thys translation wyth the translations of the Bible & fynde that they disagre: do not forth wyth dislyke either of them, but first consult men of learnynge & iudgement in the knowledge of tonges, and knowe that God hath reueyled to his seruant Leo Iudas (whose translation I haue folowed) those thynges that were vnknowne to thē that before hym translated the Psalter out of the Ebrue.

closer.dateline: At London the .xx. daye of September. In the yere of our Lorde. M.D.xlix.
